Front: What are the main parts of an animal cell?
Back: Nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria, ribosomes.

Front: What are the main parts of a plant cell?
Back: Nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria, ribosomes, cell wall, vacuole, chloroplasts.
Controls cell activities and contains genetic material.

Front: What is the function of the cell membrane?
Back: Controls what enters and leaves the cell.

Front: What is the function of mitochondria?
What is the function of ribosomes?
What is the function of chloroplasts?
What is the function of the cell wall?

Back: Movement of particles from high to low concentration.
Movement of water across a partially permeable membrane.
Movement of particles against a concentration gradient using energy.
Cell division for growth and repair.
An unspecialised cell that can become other cell types.
A group of similar cells working together.
A group of tissues working together.
A group of organs working together.
System that transports blood around the body.

Front: What is the function of the heart?
What is the function of arteries?
Back: Carry blood away from the heart.

Front: What is the function of veins?
What is the function of capillaries?

Back: Plasma, red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets.

Front: What is the function of red blood cells?
What is the function of white blood cells?
What is the function of platelets?

Back: The temperature an enzyme works best at.
They change shape and stop working.
Breaking down food into soluble substances.

Front: What is the function of the stomach?
Back: Produces acid and enzymes to digest food.

Front: What is the function of the small intestine?
What is the word equation for aerobic respiration?
What is anaerobic respiration in animals?
Back: Respiration without oxygen producing lactic acid.

Front: What is the word equation for anaerobic respiration in plants?

Back: Process plants use to make food.

Front: What is the word equation for photosynthesis?

Back: A green pigment that absorbs light.
A factor that limits the rate of a process.

Front: What types of pathogens are there?

Back: A disease that can be spread.
A disease that cannot be spread.
When bacteria are no longer killed by antibiotics.
The process where better-adapted organisms survive.
The change in species over time.
A section of DNA that codes for a protein.
An organism that makes its own food.
An organism that breaks down dead material.
A gas that traps heat (e.g. CO₂).

Front: What is the role of bacteria in ecosystems?

Back: Learn key definitions and processes clearly and accurately.
